ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Writing technique, as it applies to the construction of an engaging fictional narrative with realistic characters. We also learned a lot about present practices and trends in the publishing industry, from editing to BookTok.
I learned about some practical skills that can help with creative writing and novel writing.
I learned the nuances of the novelwriting industry and improved my own creative writing skills.
I learned a lot about the structure and formatting of a modern realistic fiction novel as well as aspects of the publishing and marketing industry.
I learned the mechanics of long-form fiction writing while getting an in-depth look at the novel writing and publishing industry.

Learned some basics of how to write a novel: structure, POV, word choice, dialogue, etc. Learned some tips on the writing process. Wrote the first 20-25 pages of a book. Learned about writing industry.
Learned to analyze the technical aspects of writing a novel. Also learned about the book publishing industry, which was fascinating.

I learned so much about creative writing - how to sequence scenes, ways to enter in to a scene, ways to create natural dialogue, methods for character development. I definitely learned to lean into my strengths and trust my voice.

The technical skills used in writing and composing novels. Balancing characters, plot, story, setting, description, narrative, and pacing in full-length chapters. Analyzing novels for successful and weak elements. Introduction to the publishing industry

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is a wonderful balance of writing technique and info about the publishing industry! My only complaint was that it wasn't longerit made Mondays the highlight of my week.

Strengths: opportunity to learn about craft and the industry, guest speakers, the textbook, knowledgable professor, professor's willingness to review drafts and meet with students, in-class creative writing exercises
Weaknesses: Grading seemed somewhat arbitrary, I also feel like we could have done more with the books we read either for assignments or in class

This course was great! For someone like me who usually has written academic papers, the change to creative writing is actually quite relaxing and uses a different part of the brain. I don't have any major complaints!

Strengths- I loved how the class felt like a close-knit writers circle where we were able to freely share our thoughts and ask questions without judgment. I loved how creative we were allowed to be and how we got to develop our very own novel idea!

Weaknesses- It felt a little disorganized at times.

We occasionally did in class writing exercises and had nice opportunities to volunteer to share what we wrote and to learn other people's style of writing. There was a diverse class with different styles and experiences in writing.
Sometimes I felt a bit lost on how to improve.

The course was also well-structured and paced very well. Assignments were carefully chosen and very meaningful, so it never felt like we were given busy work. Also, Prof. Friedland brings in very interesting speakers and it was fascinating to learn about the book industry from them. 

I wish that the course pushed us to write more of our own novel. For our midterm, we wrote a chapter for one of the books we were reading and for the final, we wrote a chapter of our own novel. I found the final to be incredibly meaningful and wished that we could have spent more time on it. Perhaps it would have been nice if some of our homework assignments were to write a first chapter of our novel, second chapter of our novel, etc.

Strengths: I loved how we had weekly writing assignments that allowed us to practice the strategies that we learned each week. I think there was a good pace of books that we read and a good selection that was very diverse and allowed us to look at different styles of writing to learn from. I also really enjoyed all of the speakers that the professor brought in and how we focused on both the writing process and the publishing industry.
Weaknesses: I think that maybe we could have had a writing partner earlier on and have more time taken during class for us to meet with each other, but no big weaknesses.

Strengths - insightful professor with helpful criticism and encouragement + first-hand knowledge and insight with the novel writing industry, guest speakers including authors, agents, publishers. sense of community among an academically diverse group of aspiring writers, individual and group work. Relatively light reading load for a writing class (3 mid-sized novels)

Weaknesses - probably could have used 1 or 2 more longer writing assignments (as opposed to a double-spaced 12-15 page midterm and 20-25 page final), but Professor Friedland seems to really want us to enjoy the class and not stress at the workload. Overall very solid!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professor and class worked together to facilitate as close to a normal seminar environment as could be created over Zoom. Much use was made of breakout rooms, the chat, and the "raise hand" feature. Zoom was also wonderful in that it allowed for a variety of exciting guest speakers.
-Review of drafts and willingness to meet with students was really great

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! To quote one of my classmates, this class made me stop hating Mondaysit was engaging, informative, and fun. Writers of all skill levels will feel comfortable here and will find ways to grow.

If you are interested in creative writing and novel writing, yes! This course provided some of the more practical writing strategies I could apply to my writing, compared to other creative writing classes at Yale. Professor Friedland is also very generous with her time and willingness to help

Yes! Prof. Friedland is an amazing instructor and it's really just fun to sit and talk about books for two hours every week! The weekly assignments are very doable and the midterm and final aren't insanely difficult.
Yes, it was very enjoyable and really useful for someone looking to go into novel writing as a career.

Yes, this was a nice class and you get to practice with writing. Professor Friedland brought in a lot of guest speakers including authors and people in the book selling industry to give new insights and perspectives on the writing process and industry. This was a class for all levels including intro although the make up of the class does have very strong writers which at times make you feel like everyone is more experienced than you. The class is a nice chance to practice your writing, find your style through experimentation with different POVs and genres, and learn more about writing and the industry. I was not a big fan of Goon Squad, but I did enjoy the other books. Would recommend.
Yes!  I liked the class a lot!  Prof Friedland cares a lot about helping you improve and it was a nice atmosphere.
Yes, I recommend this course to another student.

Yes, what a fun class! I thought it was a really supportive environment and not stressful at all, which creative writing can sometimes be. The speakers were amazing too, including pulitzer prize winner Andrew Sean Greer, and the professor always makes herself available and has really helpful feedback.

Yes! Very approachable course for anyone who enjoys or is trying to enjoy writing longer pieces of fiction. Allows you to learn necessary skills but also gives you freedom to take risks and do what you want.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Once a week seminar for about 2 hours; must be attended live with no recordings
